text.Prompt:
Here's new tech that'll make wearables as non-invasive as a Band-Aid. Japanese researchers have created a printable conducive ink on cloth, which means your boxer briefs or sports bra could one day track your heart rate (among other things).

In an effort to make electronic wearables more, well, wearable, a team at the University of Tokyo developed the ink and announced it yesterday. In a single-step process, electrodes and wires can be printed on both surfaces of the textile using the wonder ink. This new super cloth is also way softer and stretchier than today's harder, more rigid wearables and printed electronics.Even when stretched to three times its length, the ink remained highly conducive.

This new material is somewhat similar to the conducive yarn teased at Google I/O this year, which Levi's is reportedly using to make your jeans a giant touchpad. The goal there is to swipe, pinch, tap, and drag your fingers across these smart threads to answer calls or turn off lights, just like you would on a mousepad or smartphone. (Read about our hands-on with this magic fabric here.)

Advertisement

The Tokyo researchers' ink, though, seems a lot stretchier and allows manufacturers to make wearables that'll be as skintight as fake tattoos. Yep, that's right. Tech tattoos.

The future is now.

G/O Media may get a commission 10% off 10% off Wish A gift for literally everybody.

[University of Tokyo via TechCrunch]

Image credits Someya Laboratory

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: A team of researchers at the University of Tokyo have developed a new conductive ink which can be printed on textile materials to create electronic circuits.  The conductive ink is soft and stretchy, and can be stretched to three times its length without losing conductivity, which allows for the creation of flexible electronic circuits on fabric materials.  The ink could be used to create wearable electronic devices that are soft and stretchy like clothing, as well as electronic sensors and circuits embedded in textiles.  The development of the conductive ink represents a significant step forward in the field of printable electronics, and could have numerous applications in the creation of flexible electronic devices and sensors.
text.Response B: Researchers at the University of Tokyo have developed a stretchable conductive ink that can be used to print onto cloth, which could be used to create wearable devices such as a smart bra that tracks your heart rate. This ink is very stretchable, and remained highly conductive even when stretched to three times its length. It could also be used to create devices such as a smart touchpad. The researchers are currently working on a technique to print electronics on the fabric using a 3D printer.

Generate a summary:

Response A

A team of researchers at the University of Tokyo have developed a new conductive ink which can be printed on textile materials to create electronic circuits. The conductive ink is soft and stretchy, and can be stretched to three times its length without losing conductivity, which allows for the creation of flexible electronic circuits on fabric materials. The ink could be used to create wearable electronic devices that are soft and stretchy like clothing, as well as electronic sensors and circuits embedded in textiles. The development of the conductive ink represents a significant step forward in the field of printable electronics, and could have numerous applications in the creation of flexible electronic devices and sensors.

Response B

Researchers at the University of Tokyo have developed a stretchable conductive ink that can be used to print onto cloth, which could be used to create wearable devices such as a smart bra that tracks your heart rate. This ink is very stretchable, and remained highly conductive even when stretched to three times its length. It could also be used to create devices such as a smart touchpad. The researchers are currently working on a technique to print electronics on the fabric using a 3D printer.
